highlight-source-python notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" dir=\"auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"import CloudFlare\n\ndef main():\n    zone_name = 'example.com'\n\n    cf = CloudFlare.CloudFlare()\n\n    # query for the zone name and expect only one value back\n    try:\n        zones = cf.zones.get(params = {'name':zone_name,'per_page':1})\n    except CloudFlare.exceptions.CloudFlareAPIError as e:\n        exit('/zones.get %d %s - api call failed' % (e, e))\n    except Exception as e:\n        exit('/zones.get - %s - api call failed' % (e))\n\n    if len(zones) == 0:\n        exit('No zones found')\n\n    # extract the zone_id which is needed to process that zone\n    zone = zones[0]\n    zone_id = zone['id']\n\n    # request the DNS records from that zone\n    try:\n        dns_records = cf.zones.dns_records.get(zone_id)\n    except CloudFlare.exceptions.CloudFlareAPIError as e:\n        exit('/zones/dns_records.get %d %s - api call failed' % (e, e))\n\n    # print the results - first the zone name\n    print(\u0026quot;zone_id=%s zone_name=%s\u0026quot; % (zone_id, zone_name))\n\n    # then all the DNS records for that zone\n    for dns_record in dns_records:\n        r_name = dns_record['name']\n        r_type = dns_record['type']\n        r_value = dns_record['content']\n        r_id = dns_record['id']\n        print('\\t', r_id, r_name, r_type, r_value)\n\n    exit(0)\n\nif __name__ == '__main__':\n    main()\"\u003e\u003cpre\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-k\"\u003eimport\u003c/span\u003e \u003cspan class=\"pl-v\"\u003eCloudFlare\u003c/span\u003e.\u003cspan class=\"pl-v\"\u003eCloudFlare\u003c/span\u003e(\u003cspan class=\"pl-s1\"\u003eemail\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-c1\"\u003e=\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e'user@example.com'\u003c/span\u003e, \u003cspan class=\"pl-s1\"\u003ekey\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-c1\"\u003e=\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e'00000000000000000000000000000000'\u003c/span\u003e, \u003cspan class=\"pl-s1\"\u003ecerttoken\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-c1\"\u003e=\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e'v1.0-...'\u003c/span\u003e)\n\n    \u003cspan class=\"pl-c\"\u003e# An authenticated call using using a stored profile (see below)\u003c/span\u003e\n    \u003cspan class=\"pl-s1\"\u003ecf\u003c/span\u003e \u003cspan class=\"pl-c1\"\u003e=\u003c/span\u003e \u003cspan class=\"pl-v\"\u003eCloudFlare\u003c/span\u003e.\u003cspan class=\"pl-v\"\u003eCloudFlare\u003c/span\u003e(\u003cspan class=\"pl-s1\"\u003eprofile\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-c1\"\u003e=\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\"CompanyX\"\u003c/span\u003e))\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eIf the account email and API key are not passed when you create the class, then they are retrieved from either the users exported shell environment variables or the .cloudflare.cfg or ~/.cloudflare.cfg or ~/.cloudflare/cloudflare.cfg files, in that order.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eIf you're using an API Token, any \u003ccode\u003ecloudflare.cfg\u003c/code\u003e file must either not contain an \u003ccode\u003eemail\u003c/code\u003e and \u003ccode\u003ekey\u003c/code\u003e attribute (or they can be zero length strings) and the \u003ccode\u003eCLOUDFLARE_EMAIL\u003c/code\u003e \u003ccode\u003eCLOUDFLARE_API_KEY\u003c/code\u003e environment variable must be unset (or zero length strings), otherwise the token (\u003ccode\u003eCLOUDFLARE_API_TOKEN\u003c/code\u003e or \u003ccode\u003etoken\u003c/code\u003e attribute) will not be used.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eThere is one call that presently doesn't need any email or token certification (the \u003cem\u003e/ips\u003c/em\u003e call); hence you can test without any values saved away.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"markdown-heading\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ch3 tabindex=\"-1\" class=\"heading-element\" dir=\"auto\"\u003eUsing shell environment variables\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ca id=\"user-content-using-shell-environment-variables\" class=\"anchor-element\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003eCLOUDFLARE_EMAIL\u003c/code\u003e has replaced \u003ccode\u003eCF_API_EMAIL\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003eCLOUDFLARE_API_KEY\u003c/code\u003e has replaced \u003ccode\u003eCF_API_KEY\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003eCLOUDFLARE_API_TOKEN\u003c/code\u003e has replaced \u003ccode\u003eCF_API_TOKEN\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003eCLOUDFLARE_API_CERTKEY\u003c/code\u003e has replaced \u003ccode\u003eCF_API_CERTKEY\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eAdditionally, these two variables are available for testing purposes:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003eCLOUDFLARE_API_EXTRAS\u003c/code\u003e has replaced \u003ccode\u003eCF_API_EXTRAS\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003eCLOUDFLARE_API_URL\u003c/code\u003e has replaced \u003ccode\u003eCF_API_URL\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eThe older environment variable names can still be used.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"highlight highlight-source-shell notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" dir=\"auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"$ export CLOUDFLARE_EMAIL='user@example.com'\n$ export CLOUDFLARE_API_KEY='00000000000000000000000000000000'\n$ export CLOUDFLARE_API_CERTKEY='v1.0-...'\n$\"\u003e\u003cpre\u003e$ \u003cspan class=\"pl-k\"\u003eexport\u003c/span\u003e CLOUDFLARE_EMAIL=\u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-pds\"\u003e'\u003c/span\u003euser@example.com\u003cspan class=\"pl-pds\"\u003e'\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\n$ \u003cspan class=\"pl-k\"\u003eexport\u003c/span\u003e CLOUDFLARE_API_KEY=\u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-pds\"\u003e'\u003c/span\u003e00000000000000000000000000000000\u003cspan class=\"pl-pds\"\u003e'\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\n$ \u003cspan class=\"pl-k\"\u003eexport\u003c/span\u003e CLOUDFLARE_API_CERTKEY=\u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-pds\"\u003e'\u003c/span\u003ev1.0-...\u003cspan class=\"pl-pds\"\u003e'\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\n$\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eOr if using API Token.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"highlight highlight-source-shell notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" dir=\"auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"$ export CLOUDFLARE_API_TOKEN='00000000000000000000000000000000'\n$ export CLOUDFLARE_API_CERTKEY='v1.0-...'\n$\"\u003e\u003cpre\u003e$ \u003cspan class=\"pl-k\"\u003eexport\u003c/span\u003e CLOUDFLARE_API_TOKEN=\u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-pds\"\u003e'\u003c/span\u003e00000000000000000000000000000000\u003cspan class=\"pl-pds\"\u003e'\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\n$ \u003cspan class=\"pl-k\"\u003eexport\u003c/span\u003e CLOUDFLARE_API_CERTKEY=\u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-pds\"\u003e'\u003c/span\u003ev1.0-...\u003cspan class=\"pl-pds\"\u003e'\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\n$\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eThese are optional environment variables; however, they do override the values set within a configuration file.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"markdown-heading\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ch3 tabindex=\"-1\" class=\"heading-element\" dir=\"auto\"\u003eUsing configuration file to store email and keys\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ca id=\"user-content-using-configuration-file-to-store-email-and-keys\" 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z\"\u003e\u003c/path\u003e\u003c/svg\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eThe default profile name is \u003ccode\u003eCloudflare\u003c/code\u003e for obvious reasons.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"highlight highlight-source-shell notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" dir=\"auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"$ cat ~/.cloudflare/cloudflare.cfg\n[Cloudflare]\nemail = user@example.com # Do not set if using an API Token\nkey = 00000000000000000000000000000000\ncerttoken = v1.0-...\nextras =\n$\"\u003e\u003cpre\u003e$ cat \u003cspan class=\"pl-k\"\u003e~\u003c/span\u003e/.cloudflare/cloudflare.cfg\n[Cloudflare]\nemail = user@example.com \u003cspan class=\"pl-c\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-c\"\u003e#\u003c/span\u003e Do not set if using an API Token\u003c/span\u003e\nkey = 00000000000000000000000000000000\ncerttoken = v1.0-...\nextras =\n$\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eMore than one profile can be stored within that file.\nHere's an example for a work and home setup (in this example work has an API Token and home uses email/key).\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"highlight highlight-source-shell notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" dir=\"auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"$ cat ~/.cloudflare/cloudflare.cfg\n[Work]\ntoken = 00000000000000000000000000000000\n[Home]\nemail = home@example.com\nkey = 00000000000000000000000000000000\n$\"\u003e\u003cpre\u003e$ cat \u003cspan class=\"pl-k\"\u003e~\u003c/span\u003e/.cloudflare/cloudflare.cfg\n[Work]\ntoken = 00000000000000000000000000000000\n[Home]\nemail = home@example.com\nkey = 00000000000000000000000000000000\n$\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eTo select a profile, use the \u003ccode\u003e--profile profile-name\u003c/code\u003e option for \u003ccode\u003ecli4\u003c/code\u003e command or use \u003ccode\u003eprofile=\"profile-name\"\u003c/code\u003e in the library call.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"highlight highlight-source-shell notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" dir=\"auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"$ cli4 --profile Work /zones | jq '.[]|.name' | wc -l\n      13\n$\n\n$ cli4 --profile Home /zones | jq '.[]|.name' | wc -l\n       1\n$\"\u003e\u003cpre\u003e$ cli4 --profile Work /zones \u003cspan class=\"pl-k\"\u003e|\u003c/span\u003e jq \u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-pds\"\u003e'\u003c/span\u003e.[]|.name\u003cspan class=\"pl-pds\"\u003e'\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e \u003cspan class=\"pl-k\"\u003e|\u003c/span\u003e wc -l\n      13\n$\n\n$ cli4 --profile Home /zones \u003cspan class=\"pl-k\"\u003e|\u003c/span\u003e jq \u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-pds\"\u003e'\u003c/span\u003e.[]|.name\u003cspan class=\"pl-pds\"\u003e'\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e \u003cspan class=\"pl-k\"\u003e|\u003c/span\u003e wc -l\n       1\n$\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eHere is the same in code.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"highlight highlight-source-python notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" dir=\"auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"#!/usr/bin/env python\n\nimport CloudFlare\n\ndef main():\n    cf = CloudFlare.CloudFlare(profile=\u0026quot;Work\u0026quot;)\n    ...\"\u003e\u003cpre\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-c\"\u003e#!/usr/bin/env python\u003c/span\u003e\n\n\u003cspan class=\"pl-k\"\u003eimport\u003c/span\u003e \u003cspan class=\"pl-v\"\u003eCloudFlare\u003c/span\u003e\n\n\u003cspan class=\"pl-k\"\u003edef\u003c/span\u003e \u003cspan class=\"pl-en\"\u003emain\u003c/span\u003e():\n    \u003cspan class=\"pl-s1\"\u003ecf\u003c/span\u003e \u003cspan class=\"pl-c1\"\u003e=\u003c/span\u003e \u003cspan class=\"pl-v\"\u003eCloudFlare\u003c/span\u003e.\u003cspan class=\"pl-v\"\u003eCloudFlare\u003c/span\u003e(\u003cspan class=\"pl-s1\"\u003eprofile\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-c1\"\u003e=\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\"Work\"\u003c/span\u003e)\n    ...\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"markdown-heading\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ch3 tabindex=\"-1\" class=\"heading-element\" dir=\"auto\"\u003ePassing your own HTTP headers to API calls\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ca 2.83Z\"\u003e\u003c/path\u003e\u003c/svg\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eThere are very specific case where a user of the library needs to add custom headers to all HTTP calls.\nThis is rarly needed.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eThe addition headers can be passed via the confuration file as follows:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"highlight highlight-source-shell notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" dir=\"auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"$ cat ~/.cloudflare/cloudflare.cfg\n...\nhttp_headers =\n        X-Header1:value\n        X-Header2: value1 value2 value3\n        X-Header3: \u0026quot;this is life as we know it\u0026quot;\n        X-Header4: 'two single quotes'\n        X-Header5:\n...\n$\"\u003e\u003cpre\u003e$ cat \u003cspan class=\"pl-k\"\u003e~\u003c/span\u003e/.cloudflare/cloudflare.cfg\n...\nhttp_headers =\n        X-Header1:value\n        X-Header2: value1 value2 value3\n        X-Header3: \u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-pds\"\u003e\"\u003c/span\u003ethis is life as we know it\u003cspan class=\"pl-pds\"\u003e\"\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\n        X-Header4: \u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-pds\"\u003e'\u003c/span\u003etwo single quotes\u003cspan class=\"pl-pds\"\u003e'\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\n        X-Header5:\n...\n$\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eEach line should have a header noun, a colon, and a verb.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eYou can also pass these via Python calls.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"highlight highlight-source-python notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" dir=\"auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"    import CloudFlare\n\n    http_headers = [\n        'X-Header1:value',\n        'X-Header2: value1 value2 value3',\n        'X-Header3: \u0026quot;this is life as we know it\u0026quot;',\n        'X-Header4: \\'two single quotes\\'',\n        'X-Header5:',\n    ]\n    cf = CloudFlare.CloudFlare(http_headers=http_headers)\n...\"\u003e\u003cpre\u003e    \u003cspan class=\"pl-k\"\u003eimport\u003c/span\u003e \u003cspan class=\"pl-v\"\u003eCloudFlare\u003c/span\u003e\n\n    \u003cspan class=\"pl-s1\"\u003ehttp_headers\u003c/span\u003e \u003cspan class=\"pl-c1\"\u003e=\u003c/span\u003e [\n        \u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e'X-Header1:value'\u003c/span\u003e,\n        \u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e'X-Header2: value1 value2 value3'\u003c/span\u003e,\n        \u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e'X-Header3: \"this is life as we know it\"'\u003c/span\u003e,\n        \u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e'X-Header4: \u003cspan class=\"pl-cce\"\u003e\\'\u003c/span\u003etwo single quotes\u003cspan class=\"pl-cce\"\u003e\\'\u003c/span\u003e'\u003c/span\u003e,\n        \u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e'X-Header5:'\u003c/span\u003e,\n    ]\n    \u003cspan class=\"pl-s1\"\u003ecf\u003c/span\u003e \u003cspan class=\"pl-c1\"\u003e=\u003c/span\u003e \u003cspan class=\"pl-v\"\u003eCloudFlare\u003c/span\u003e.\u003cspan class=\"pl-v\"\u003eCloudFlare\u003c/span\u003e(\u003cspan class=\"pl-s1\"\u003ehttp_headers\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-c1\"\u003e=\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-s1\"\u003ehttp_headers\u003c/span\u003e)\n...\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eThese header values can also be passed via \u003ccode\u003ecli4\u003c/code\u003e command (many times) - use the \u003ccode\u003e-v\u003c/code\u003e option to see the debug messages:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"$ cli4 -v --header 'X-something:' --header 'X-whatever:whatever' /zones \u0026gt; /tmp/results.json\n...\n            --header \u0026quot;X-something: \u0026quot; \\\n            --header \u0026quot;X-whatever: whatever \u0026quot; \\\n...\n$\"\u003e\u003cpre class=\"notranslate\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003e$ cli4 -v --header 'X-something:' --header 'X-whatever:whatever' /zones \u0026gt; /tmp/results.json\n...\n            --header \"X-something: \" \\\n            --header \"X-whatever: whatever \" \\\n...\n$\n\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"markdown-heading\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ch3 tabindex=\"-1\" \u003cem\u003ecerttoken\u003c/em\u003e in the configuration with a blank value (or omit the option variable fully).\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eThe \u003cem\u003eextras\u003c/em\u003e class=\"pl-pds\"\u003e'\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e cli4 /zones/\ncli4: /zones - 9103 Unknown X-Auth-Key or X-Auth-Email\n$\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eMore than one call can be done on the same command line. In this mode, the connection is preserved between calls.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"highlight highlight-source-shell notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" dir=\"auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"$ cli4 /user/organizations /user/invites\n...\n$\"\u003e\u003cpre\u003e$ cli4 /user/organizations /user/invites\n...\n$\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eNote that the output is presently two JSON structures one after the other - so less useful that you may think.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eFinally, a command that provides more than one error response.\nThis is simulated by passing an invalid IPv4 address to a DNS record creation.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"highlight highlight-source-shell notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" dir=\"auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"$ cli4 --post name='foo' type=A content=\u0026quot;NOT-A-VALID-IP-ADDRESS\u0026quot; /zones/:example.com/dns_records\ncli4: /zones/:example.com/dns_records - 9005 Content for A record is invalid. Must be a valid IPv4 address\ncli4: /zones/:example.com/dns_records - 1004 DNS Validation Error\n$\"\u003e\u003cpre\u003e$ cli4 --post name=\u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-pds\"\u003e'\u003c/span\u003efoo\u003cspan class=\"pl-pds\"\u003e'\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e type=A content=\u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-pds\"\u003e\"\u003c/span\u003eNOT-A-VALID-IP-ADDRESS\u003cspan class=\"pl-pds\"\u003e\"\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e /zones/:example.com/dns_records\ncli4: /zones/:example.com/dns_records - 9005 Content \u003cspan class=\"pl-k\"\u003efor\u003c/span\u003e A record is invalid. cf.zones.get(params={'name': zone_name})\n    zone_id = zone_info['id']\n\n    dns_name = sys.argv[2]\n    dns_records = cf.zones.dns_records.get(zone_id, params={'name':dns_name + '.' + zone_name})\n    for dns_record in dns_records:\n        dns_record_id = dns_record['id']\n        r = cf.zones.dns_records.delete(zone_id, dns_record_id)\n    exit(0)\n\nif __name__ == '__main__':\n calls can be called from the command line via the \u003ccode\u003ecli4\u003c/code\u003e command.\nAdditionally, the \u003ccode\u003ecli4\u003c/code\u003e command will convert domain name or account name prefixed with a colon (\u003ccode\u003e:\u003c/code\u003e) into the correct identifier.\ne.g. to view \u003ccode\u003eexample.com\u003c/code\u003e you can use \u003ccode\u003ecli4 /zones/:example.com\u003c/code\u003e.\nYou can pass the zone identifier (or account identifier or any identifier) with a colon followed by the identifier as a hex number 32 characters use.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eThe simplest form is \u003ccode\u003eitem=value\u003c/code\u003e. This passes the value as a string within the APIs JSON data.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eIf you need a numeric value passed then \u003ccode\u003e==\u003c/code\u003e can be used to force the value to be treated as a numeric value within the APIs JSON data.\nFor example: \u003ccode\u003eitem==value\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eif you need to pass a list of items; then \u003ccode\u003e[]\u003c/code\u003e can be used. For example:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"highlight highlight-source-shell notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" dir=\"auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"pool_id1=\u0026quot;11111111111111111111111111111111\u0026quot;\npool_id2=\u0026quot;22222222222222222222222222222222\u0026quot;\npool_id3=\u0026quot;33333333333333333333333333333333\u0026quot;\ncli4 --post global_pools=\u0026quot;[ ${pool_id1}, ${pool_id2}, ${pool_id3} ]\u0026quot; region_pools=\u0026quot;[ ]\u0026quot; /user/load_balancers/maps\"\u003e\u003cpre\u003epool_id1=\u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-pds\"\u003e\"\u003c/span\u003e11111111111111111111111111111111\u003cspan class=\"pl-pds\"\u003e\"\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\npool_id2=\u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-pds\"\u003e\"\u003c/span\u003e22222222222222222222222222222222\u003cspan class=\"pl-pds\"\u003e\"\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\npool_id3=\u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-pds\"\u003e\"\u003c/span\u003e33333333333333333333333333333333\u003cspan class=\"pl-pds\"\u003e\"\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\ncli4 --post global_pools=\u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-pds\"\u003e\"\u003c/span\u003e[ \u003cspan class=\"pl-smi\"\u003e${pool_id1}\u003c/span\u003e, \u003cspan class=\"pl-smi\"\u003e${pool_id2}\u003c/span\u003e, \u003cspan class=\"pl-smi\"\u003e${pool_id3}\u003c/span\u003e ]\u003cspan class=\"pl-pds\"\u003e\"\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e region_pools=\u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-pds\"\u003e\"\u003c/span\u003e[ ]\u003cspan class=\"pl-pds\"\u003e\"\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e /user/load_balancers/maps\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eData or parameters can be either named or unnamed.\nIt can not be both.\nNamed is the majority format; as described above.\nUnnamed parameters simply don't have anything before the \u003ccode\u003e=\u003c/code\u003e sign, as in \u003ccode\u003e=value\u003c/code\u003e.\nThis format is presently only used by the Cloudflare Load Balancer API calls.\nFor example:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"highlight highlight-source-shell notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" dir=\"auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"cli4 --put =\u0026quot;00000000000000000000000000000000\u0026quot; /user/load_balancers/maps/:00000000000000000000000000000000/region/:WNAM\"\u003e\u003cpre\u003ecli4 --put =\u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-pds\"\u003e\"\u003c/span\u003e00000000000000000000000000000000\u003cspan class=\"pl-pds\"\u003e\"\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e /user/load_balancers/maps/:00000000000000000000000000000000/region/:WNAM\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eData can also be uploaded from file contents. Using the \u003ccode\u003eitem=@filename\u003c/code\u003e format will open the file and the contents uploaded in the POST.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"markdown-heading\" dir=\"auto\"\u003eThe default output from the CLI command is in JSON.\nIt can also output YAML format (i.e. human readable).\nThis is controled by the \u003ccode\u003e--yaml\u003c/code\u003e or \u003ccode\u003e--json\u003c/code\u003e flags (JSON is the default).\nThere is also a \u003ccode\u003e--ndjson\u003c/code\u003e flag for use with line based JSON data - this is mainly used for log data.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eAdditonally the output can be plain text or binary image format depending on the results from the API call (some calls results in non JSON results).\nThe \u003ccode\u003e--image\u003c/code\u003e flag will return the data in the same format as the API's results.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"markdown-heading\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ch3 '{\u0026quot;id\u0026quot;:.id,\u0026quot;name\u0026quot;:.name,\u0026quot;type\u0026quot;:.type,\u0026quot;content\u0026quot;:.content}'\n{\n  \u0026quot;id\u0026quot;: \u003ccode\u003eexample_paging_thru_zones.sh\u003c/code\u003e).\nNote the use of \u003ccode\u003e==\u003c/code\u003e to pass a number vs a string as paramater.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"highlight highlight-source-shell notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" dir=\"auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\":\ntmp=/tmp/$$_\ntrap \u0026quot;rm ${tmp}; exit 0\u0026quot; 0 1 2 15\nPAGE=0\nwhile true\ndo\n        cli4 --raw per_page==5 page==${PAGE} /zones \u0026gt; ${tmp}\n        domains=`jq -c '.|.result|.[]|.name' \u0026lt; ${tmp} | tr -d '\u0026quot;'`\n        result_info=`jq -c '.|.result_info' \u0026lt; ${tmp}`\n        COUNT=`      echo \u0026quot;${result_info}\u0026quot; | jq .count`\n        PAGE=`       echo \u0026quot;${result_info}\u0026quot; | jq .page`\n        PER_PAGE=`   echo \u0026quot;${result_info}\u0026quot; | jq .per_page`\n        TOTAL_COUNT=`echo \u0026quot;${result_info}\u0026quot; | jq .total_count`\n        TOTAL_PAGES=`echo \u0026quot;${result_info}\u0026quot; | jq .total_pages`\n        echo COUNT=${COUNT} PAGE=${PAGE} PER_PAGE=${PER_PAGE} TOTAL_COUNT=${TOTAL_COUNT} TOTAL_PAGES=${TOTAL_PAGES} -- ${domains}\n        if [ \u0026quot;${PAGE}\u0026quot; == \u0026quot;${TOTAL_PAGES}\u0026quot; ]\n        then\n                ## last section\n                break\n        fi\n        # grab the next page\n See the API page in order to see which API calls do this.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"highlight highlight-source-shell notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" dir=\"auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"$ ACCOUNT_ID=\u0026quot;00000000000000000000000000000000\u0026quot;\n$ LIST_ID=\u0026quot;00000000000000000000000000000000\u0026quot;\n$\n$ cli4 --raw /accounts/::${ACCOUNT_ID}/rules/lists/::${LIST_ID}/items \u0026gt; /tmp/page1.json\n$ after=`jq -r '.result_info.cursors.after' \u0026lt; /tmp/page1.json`\n$ echo \u0026quot;after=$after\u0026quot;\nafter=Mxm4GVmKjYbFjy2VxMPipnJigm1M_s6lCS9ABR9wx-RM2A\n$\"\u003e\u003cpre\u003e$ ACCOUNT_ID=\u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-pds\"\u003e\"\u003c/span\u003e00000000000000000000000000000000\u003cspan class=\"pl-pds\"\u003e\"\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\n$ LIST_ID=\u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-pds\"\u003e\"\u003c/span\u003e00000000000000000000000000000000\u003cspan class=\"pl-pds\"\u003e\"\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\n$\n$ cli4 --raw /accounts/::\u003cspan class=\"pl-smi\"\u003e${ACCOUNT_ID}\u003c/span\u003e/rules/lists/::\u003cspan class=\"pl-smi\"\u003e${LIST_ID}\u003c/span\u003e/items \u003cspan class=\"pl-k\"\u003e\u0026gt;\u003c/span\u003e /tmp/page1.json\n$ after=\u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-pds\"\u003e`\u003c/span\u003ejq -r \u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-pds\"\u003e'\u003c/span\u003e.result_info.cursors.after\u003cspan class=\"pl-pds\"\u003e'\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e \u003cspan class=\"pl-k\"\u003e\u0026lt;\u003c/span\u003e /tmp/page1.json\u003cspan class=\"pl-pds\"\u003e`\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\n$ \u003cspan class=\"pl-c1\"\u003eecho\u003c/span\u003e \u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-pds\"\u003e\"\u003c/span\u003eafter=\u003cspan class=\"pl-smi\"\u003e$after\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-pds\"\u003e\"\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\nafter=Mxm4GVmKjYbFjy2VxMPipnJigm1M_s6lCS9ABR9wx-RM2A\n$\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eOnce we have the \u003ccode\u003eafter\u003c/code\u003e value, we can pass it along in order to read the next hunk of values. We finish when \u003ccode\u003eafter\u003c/code\u003e returns as null (or isn't present).\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"highlight highlight-source-shell notranslate position-relative sum { countryMap { bytes, requests, clientCountryName } }\n              dimensions { date }\n            }\n          }\n        }\n      }\n    \"\"\" % (zone_id, date_before[0:10], date_after[0:10])\n\n    r = cf.graphql.post(data={'query':query})\n\n    httpRequests1dGroups = zone_info = class="pl-en">main</span>()</pre></div><p dir="auto">This example works when there are less than 50 zones (50 is the default number of values returned from a query like this).</p><p dir="auto">Now lets expand on that and add code to show the IPv6 and SSL status of the zones. Lets also query 100 zones.</p><div class="highlight highlight-source-python notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="import CloudFlaredef main():    cf = CloudFlare.CloudFlare()    zones = cf.zones.get(params = {'per_page':100})    for zone in zones:        zone_id = zone['id']        zone_name = zone['name']        settings_ssl = cf.zones.settings.ssl.get(zone_id)        ssl_status = settings_ssl['value']        settings_ipv6 = cf.zones.settings.ipv6.get(zone_id)        ipv6_status = settings_ipv6['value']        print("zone_id=%s zone_name=%s" % (zone_id, zone_name))        print("ssl_status=%s ipv6_status=%s" % (ssl_status, ipv6_status))if __name__ == '__main__':    main()"><pre><span dir="auto">Providing Cloudflare Username and API Key</h2><a id="user-content-providing-cloudflare-username-and-api-key" class="anchor-element" aria-label="Permalink: Providing Cloudflare Username and API Key" href="#providing-cloudflare-username-and-api-key"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><p dir="auto">When you create a <strong>CloudFlare</strong> class you can pass some combination of these four core parameters.</p><ul dir="auto"><li><code>email</code> - The account email (only if an API Key is being used)</li><li><code>api</code> - The API Key (if coding prior to Issue-114 being merged)</li><li><code>token</code> - The API Token (if coding after to Issue-114)</li><li><code>certtoken</code> - Optional Origin-CA Certificate Token</li></ul><p dir="auto">This parameter controls how the data is returned from a successful call (see notes below).</p><ul dir="auto"><li><code>raw</code> - An optional Raw flag (True/False) - defaults to False</li></ul><p dir="auto">Timeouts (10s) and Retries (5) are configured by default. Should you wish to override them, use these settings:</p><ul dir="auto"><li><code>global_request_timeout</code> - How long before each API call to Cloudflare should time out (in seconds)</li><li><code>max_requests_retries</code> - How many times to retry an API call when DNS lookups, socket connections, or connect timeouts occur.</li></ul><blockquote><p dir="auto">NOTE: <code>max_request_retries</code> is only available when <code>use_sessions</code> is not disabled.</p></blockquote><p dir="auto">The following paramaters are for debug and/or development usage</p><ul dir="auto"><li><code>debug</code> - An optional Debug flag (True/False) - defaults to False</li><li><code>use_sessions</code> - An optional Use-Sessions flag (True/False) - defaults to True</li><li><code>profile</code> - An optional Profile name (the default is <code>Cloudflare</code>)</li><li><code>base_url</code> - An optional Base URL (only used for development)</li></ul><p dir="auto">email=None, key=None, token=None, certtoken=None, debug=False, raw=False, use_sessions=True, profile=None, base_url=None):</p><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h3 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">Issue-114</h3><a id="user-content-issue-114" class="anchor-element" aria-label="Permalink: Issue-114" href="#issue-114"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><p dir="auto">After <a href="https://github.com/cloudflare/python-cloudflare/issues/114" data-hovercard-type="issue" data-hovercard-url="/cloudflare/python-cloudflare/issues/114/hovercard">Issue-114</a> was coded and merged, the use of <code>token</code> and <code>key</code> changed; however, is backward compatible (amazingly!).</p><p dir="auto">If you are using only the API Token, then don't include the API Email. If you are coding prior to Issue-114, then the API Key can also be used as an API Token if the API Email is not used.</p><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h3 tabindex="-1" they are retrieved from either the users exported shell environment variables or the .cloudflare.cfg or ~/.cloudflare.cfg or ~/.cloudflare/cloudflare.cfg files, in that order.</p><p dir="auto">If you're using an API Token, any <code>cloudflare.cfg</code> file must either not contain an <code>email</code> and <code>key</code> attribute (or they can be zero length strings) and the <code>CLOUDFLARE_EMAIL</code> <code>CLOUDFLARE_API_KEY</code> environment variable must be unset (or zero length strings), otherwise the token (<code>CLOUDFLARE_API_TOKEN</code> or <code>token</code> attribute) will not be used.</p><p dir="auto">There is one call that presently doesn't need any email or token certification (the <em>/ips</em> call); hence you can test without any values saved away.</p><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h3 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">Using shell environment variables</h3><a id="user-content-using-shell-environment-variables" 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><p dir="auto">Note (for latest version of code):</p><ul dir="auto"><li><code>CLOUDFLARE_EMAIL</code> has replaced <code>CF_API_EMAIL</code>.</li><li><code>CLOUDFLARE_API_KEY</code> has replaced <code>CF_API_KEY</code>.</li><li><code>CLOUDFLARE_API_TOKEN</code> has replaced <code>CF_API_TOKEN</code>.</li><li><code>CLOUDFLARE_API_CERTKEY</code> has replaced <code>CF_API_CERTKEY</code>.</li></ul><p dir="auto">Additionally, these two variables are available for testing purposes:</p><ul dir="auto"><li><code>CLOUDFLARE_API_EXTRAS</code> has replaced <code>CF_API_EXTRAS</code>.</li><li><code>CLOUDFLARE_API_URL</code> has replaced <code>CF_API_URL</code>.</li></ul><p dir="auto">The older environment variable names can still be used.</p><div class="highlight highlight-source-shell notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="$ export CLOUDFLARE_EMAIL='user@example.com'$ export CLOUDFLARE_API_KEY='00000000000000000000000000000000'$ export CLOUDFLARE_API_CERTKEY='v1.0-...'$"><pre>$ <span class="pl-k">export</span> CLOUDFLARE_EMAIL=<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>user@example.com<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>$ <span class="pl-k">export</span> CLOUDFLARE_API_KEY=<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>00000000000000000000000000000000<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>$ <span class="pl-k">export</span> CLOUDFLARE_API_CERTKEY=<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>v1.0-...<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>$</pre></div><p dir="auto">Or if using API Token.</p><div class="highlight highlight-source-shell notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="$ export CLOUDFLARE_API_TOKEN='00000000000000000000000000000000'$ export CLOUDFLARE_API_CERTKEY='v1.0-...'$"><pre>$ <span class="pl-k">export</span> CLOUDFLARE_API_TOKEN=<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>00000000000000000000000000000000<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>$ <span class="pl-k">export</span> CLOUDFLARE_API_CERTKEY=<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>v1.0-...<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>$</pre></div><p dir="auto">These are optional environment variables; however, they do override the values set within a configuration file.</p><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h3 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">Using configuration file to store email and keys</h3><a id="user-content-using-configuration-file-to-store-email-and-keys" class="anchor-element" aria-label="Permalink: Using configuration file to store email and keys" href="#using-configuration-file-to-store-email-and-keys"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><p dir="auto">The default profile name is <code>Cloudflare</code> for obvious reasons.</p><div class="highlight highlight-source-shell notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="$ cat ~/.cloudflare/cloudflare.cfg[Cloudflare]email = user@example.com # Do not set if using an API Tokenkey = 00000000000000000000000000000000certtoken = v1.0-...extras =$"><pre>$ cat <span class="pl-k">~</span>/.cloudflare/cloudflare.cfg[Cloudflare]email = user@example.com <span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c">#</span> Do not set if using an API Token</span>key = 00000000000000000000000000000000certtoken = v1.0-...extras =$</pre></div><p dir="auto">More than one profile can be stored within that file.Here's an example for a work and home setup (in this example work has an API Token and home uses email/key).</p><div class="highlight highlight-source-shell notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="$ cat ~/.cloudflare/cloudflare.cfg[Work]token = 00000000000000000000000000000000[Home]email = home@example.comkey = 00000000000000000000000000000000$"><pre>$ cat <span class="pl-k">~</span>/.cloudflare/cloudflare.cfg[Work]token = 00000000000000000000000000000000[Home]email = home@example.comkey = 00000000000000000000000000000000$</pre></div><p dir="auto">To select a profile, use the <code>--profile profile-name</code> option for <code>cli4</code> command or use <code>profile="profile-name"</code> in the library call.</p><div class="highlight highlight-source-shell notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="$ cli4 --profile Work /zones | jq '.[]|.name' | wc -l      13$$ cli4 --profile Home /zones | jq '.[]|.name' | wc -l       1$"><pre>$ cli4 --profile Work /zones <span class="pl-k">|</span> jq <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>.[]|.name<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span> <span class="pl-k">|</span> wc -l      13$$ cli4 --profile Home /zones <span class="pl-k">|</span> jq <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>.[]|.name<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span> <span class="pl-k">|</span> wc -l       1$</pre></div><p dir="auto">Here is the same in code.</p><div class="highlight highlight-source-python notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="#!/usr/bin/env pythonimport CloudFlaredef main():    cf = CloudFlare.CloudFlare(profile="Work")    ..."><pre><span class="pl-c">#!/usr/bin/env python</span><span class="pl-k">import</span> <span class="pl-v">CloudFlare</span><span class="pl-k">def</span> <span class="pl-en">main</span>():    <span class="pl-s1">cf</span> <span class="pl-c1">=</span> <span class="pl-v">CloudFlare</span>.<span class="pl-v">CloudFlare</span>(<span class="pl-s1">profile</span><span class="pl-c1">=</span><span class="pl-s">"Work"</span>)    ...</pre></div><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h3 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">Passing your own HTTP headers to API calls</h3><a id="user-content-passing-your-own-http-headers-to-api-calls" class="anchor-element" aria-label="Permalink: Passing your own HTTP headers to API calls" href="#passing-your-own-http-headers-to-api-calls"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><p dir="auto">There are very specific case where a user of the library needs to add custom headers to all HTTP calls.This is rarly needed.</p><p dir="auto">The addition headers can be passed via the confuration file as follows:</p><div class="highlight highlight-source-shell notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="$ cat ~/.cloudflare/cloudflare.cfg...http_headers =        X-Header1:value        X-Header2: value1 value2 value3        X-Header3: "this is life as we know it"        X-Header4: 'two single quotes'        X-Header5:...$"><pre>$ cat <span class="pl-k">~</span>/.cloudflare/cloudflare.cfg...http_headers =        X-Header1:value        X-Header2: value1 value2 value3        X-Header3: <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>this is life as we know it<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>        X-Header4: <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>two single quotes<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>        X-Header5:...$</pre></div><p dir="auto">Each line should have a header noun, a colon, and a verb.</p><p dir="auto">You can also pass these via Python calls.</p><div class="highlight highlight-source-python notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="    import CloudFlare    http_headers = [        'X-Header1:value',        'X-Header2: value1 value2 value3',        'X-Header3: "this is life as we know it"',        'X-Header4: \'two single quotes\'',        'X-Header5:',    ]    cf = CloudFlare.CloudFlare(http_headers=http_headers)..."><pre>    <span class="pl-k">import</span> <span class="pl-v">CloudFlare</span>    <span class="pl-s1">http_headers</span> <span class="pl-c1">=</span> [        <span class="pl-s">'X-Header1:value'</span>,        <span class="pl-s">'X-Header2: value1 value2 value3'</span>,        <span class="pl-s">'X-Header3: "this is life as we know it"'</span>,        <span class="pl-s">'X-Header4: <span class="pl-cce">\'</span>two single quotes<span class="pl-cce">\'</span>'</span>,        <span class="pl-s">'X-Header5:'</span>,    ]    <span class="pl-s1">cf</span> <span class="pl-c1">=</span> <span class="pl-v">CloudFlare</span>.<span class="pl-v">CloudFlare</span>(<span class="pl-s1">http_headers</span><span class="pl-c1">=</span><span class="pl-s1">http_headers</span>)...</pre></div><p dir="auto">These header values can also be passed via <code>cli4</code> command (many times) - use the <code>-v</code> option to see the debug messages:</p><div class="snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="$ cli4 -v --header 'X-something:' --header 'X-whatever:whatever' /zones > /tmp/results.json...            --header "X-something: " \            --header "X-whatever: whatever " \...$"><pre class="notranslate"><code>$ cli4 -v --header 'X-something:' --header 'X-whatever:whatever' /zones > /tmp/results.json...            --header "X-something: " \            --header "X-whatever: whatever " \...$</code></pre></div><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h3 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">Advanced use of configuration file for authentication based on method</h3><a id="user-content-advanced-use-of-configuration-file-for-authentication-based-on-method" class="anchor-element" aria-label="Permalink: Advanced use of configuration file for authentication based on method" href="#advanced-use-of-configuration-file-for-authentication-based-on-method"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><p dir="auto">The configuration file can have values that are both generic and specific to the method.Here's an example where a project has a different API Token for reading and writing values.</p><div class="highlight highlight-source-shell notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="$ cat ~/.cloudflare/cloudflare.cfg[Work]token = 0000000000000000000000000000000000000000token.get = 0123456789012345678901234567890123456789$"><pre>$ cat <span class="pl-k">~</span>/.cloudflare/cloudflare.cfg[Work]token = 0000000000000000000000000000000000000000token.get = 0123456789012345678901234567890123456789$</pre></div><p dir="auto">When a GET call is processed then the second token is used. For all other calls the first token is used.Here's a more explict verion of that config:</p><div class="highlight highlight-source-shell notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="$ cat ~/.cloudflare/cloudflare.cfg[Work]token.delete = 0000000000000000000000000000000000000000token.get = 0123456789012345678901234567890123456789token.patch = 0000000000000000000000000000000000000000token.post = 0000000000000000000000000000000000000000token.put = 0000000000000000000000000000000000000000$"><pre>$ cat <span class="pl-k">~</span>/.cloudflare/cloudflare.cfg[Work]token.delete = 0000000000000000000000000000000000000000token.get = 0123456789012345678901234567890123456789token.patch = 0000000000000000000000000000000000000000token.post = 0000000000000000000000000000000000000000token.put = 0000000000000000000000000000000000000000$</pre></div><p dir="auto">This can be used with email values also.</p><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h3 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">About /certificates and certtoken</h3><a id="user-content-about-certificates-and-certtoken" class="anchor-element" aria-label="Permalink: About /certificates and certtoken" href="#about-certificates-and-certtoken"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><p dir="auto">The <em>CLOUDFLARE_API_CERTKEY</em> or <em>certtoken</em> values are used for the Origin-CA <em>/certificates</em> API calls.You can leave <em>certtoken</em> in the configuration with a blank value (or omit the option variable fully).</p><p dir="auto">The <em>extras</em> values are used when adding API calls outside of the core codebase.Technically, this is only useful for internal testing within Cloudflare.You can leave <em>extras</em> in the configuration with a blank value (or omit the option variable fully).</p><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h2 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">Exceptions and return values</h2><a id="user-content-exceptions-and-return-values" class="anchor-element" aria-label="Permalink: Exceptions and return values" href="#exceptions-and-return-values"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h3 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">Response data</h3><a id="user-content-response-data" class="anchor-element" aria-label="Permalink: Response data" href="#response-data"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><p dir="auto">The response is build from the JSON in the API call.It contains the <strong>results</strong> values; but does not contain the paging values.</p><p dir="auto">You can return all the paging values by calling the class with raw=True. Here's an example without paging.</p><div class="highlight highlight-source-python notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="#!/usr/bin/env pythonimport jsonimport CloudFlaredef main():    cf = CloudFlare.CloudFlare()    zones = cf.zones.get(params={'per_page':5})    print("len=%d" % (zones.length()))if __name__ == '__main__':    main()"><pre><span class="pl-c">#!/usr/bin/env python</span><span class="pl-k">import</span> <span class="pl-s1">json</span><span class="pl-k">import</span> <span class="pl-v">CloudFlare</span><span class="pl-k">def</span> <span class="pl-en">main</span>():    <span class="pl-s1">cf</span> <span class="pl-c1">=</span> <span class="pl-v">CloudFlare</span>.<span class="pl-v">CloudFlare</span>()    <span class="pl-s1">zones</span> <span class="pl-c1">=</span> <span class="pl-s1">cf</span>.<span class="pl-s1">zones</span>.<span class="pl-en">get</span>(<span class="pl-s1">params</span><span class="pl-c1">=</span>{<span class="pl-s">'per_page'</span>:<span class="pl-c1">5</span>})    <span class="pl-en">print</span>(<span class="pl-s">"len=%d"</span> <span class="pl-c1">%</span> (<span class="pl-s1">zones</span>.<span class="pl-en">length</span>()))<span class="pl-k">if</span> <span class="pl-s1">__name__</span> <span class="pl-c1">==</span> <span class="pl-s">'__main__'</span>:    <span class="pl-en">main</span>()</pre></div><p dir="auto">The results are as follows.</p><div class="snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="5"><pre class="notranslate"><code>5</code></pre></div><p dir="auto">When you add the raw option; the APIs full structure is returned. This means the paging values can be seen.</p><div class="highlight highlight-source-python notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="#!/usr/bin/env pythonimport jsonimport CloudFlaredef main():    cf = CloudFlare.CloudFlare(raw=True)    zones = cf.zones.get(params={'per_page':5})    print("len=%d" % (zones.length()))    print(json.dumps(zones, indent=4, sort_keys=True))if __name__ == '__main__':    main()"><pre><span class="pl-c">#!/usr/bin/env python</span><span class="pl-k">import</span> <span class="pl-s1">json</span><span class="pl-k">import</span> <span class="pl-v">CloudFlare</span><span class="pl-k">def</span> <span class="pl-en">main</span>():    <span class="pl-s1">cf</span> <span class="pl-c1">=</span> <span class="pl-v">CloudFlare</span>.<span class="pl-v">CloudFlare</span>(<span class="pl-s1">raw</span><span class="pl-c1">=</span><span class="pl-c1">True</span>)    <span class="pl-s1">zones</span> <span class="pl-c1">=</span> <span class="pl-s1">cf</span>.<span class="pl-s1">zones</span>.<span class="pl-en">get</span>(<span class="pl-s1">params</span><span class="pl-c1">=</span>{<span class="pl-s">'per_page'</span>:<span class="pl-c1">5</span>})    <span class="pl-en">print</span>(<span class="pl-s">"len=%d"</span> <span class="pl-c1">%</span> (<span class="pl-s1">zones</span>.<span class="pl-en">length</span>()))    <span class="pl-en">print</span>(<span class="pl-s1">json</span>.<span class="pl-en">dumps</span>(<span class="pl-s1">zones</span>, <span class="pl-s1">indent</span><span class="pl-c1">=</span><span class="pl-c1">4</span>, <span class="pl-s1">sort_keys</span><span class="pl-c1">=</span><span class="pl-c1">True</span>))<span class="pl-k">if</span> <span class="pl-s1">__name__</span> <span class="pl-c1">==</span> <span class="pl-s">'__main__'</span>:    <span class="pl-en">main</span>()</pre></div><p dir="auto">This produces.</p><div class="snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="5{    "result": [        ...    ],    "result_info": {        "count": 5,        "page": 1,        "per_page": 5,        "total_count": 31,        "total_pages": 7    }}"><pre class="notranslate"><code>5{    "result": [        ...    ],    "result_info": {        "count": 5,        "page": 1,        "per_page": 5,        "total_count": 31,        "total_pages": 7    }}</code></pre></div><p dir="auto">A full example of paging is provided below.</p><div data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="import CloudFlare    ...    try        r = ...    except CloudFlare.exceptions.CloudFlareAPIError as e:        exit('api error: %d %s' % (e, e))    ..."><pre><span highlight-source-shell notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="$ CLOUDFLARE_EMAIL='someone@example.com' cli4 /zones/cli4: /zones - 9103 Unknown X-Auth-Key or X-Auth-Email$</pre></div><p dir="auto">More than one call can be done on the same command line. In this mode, the connection is preserved between calls.</p><div class="highlight highlight-source-shell notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="$ cli4 /user/organizations /user/invites...$"><pre>$ cli4 /user/organizations /user/invites...$</pre></div><p dir="auto">Note that the output is presently two JSON structures one after the other - so less useful that you may think.</p><p dir="auto">Finally, a command that provides more than one error response.This is simulated by passing an invalid IPv4 address to a DNS record creation.</p><div class="highlight highlight-source-shell notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="$ cli4 --post name='foo' type=A content="NOT-A-VALID-IP-ADDRESS" /zones/:example.com/dns_recordscli4: /zones/:example.com/dns_records - 9005 Content for A record is invalid. in both simple and verbose formats.</p><p dir="auto">You can see the installed path of these files directly via <code>cli4 -e</code> (or <code>cli4 --examples</code>) command.</p><div class="highlight highlight-source-shell notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="$ cli4 -ePython .py files:.../opt/homebrew/lib/python3.11/site-packages/examples/example_always_use_https.py...Bash .sh files:.../opt/homebrew/lib/python3.11/site-packages/examples/example_paging_thru_zones.sh...$"><pre>$ cli4 -ePython .py files:.../opt/homebrew/lib/python3.11/site-packages/examples/example_always_use_https.py...Bash .sh files:.../opt/homebrew/lib/python3.11/site-packages/examples/example_paging_thru_zones.sh...$</pre></div><p dir="auto">The exact path will vary depending on your system.The above example is MacOS and Python 3.9 hence the <code>/opt/homebrew/lib/python3.11/site-packages/</code> path.One Linux, the Python pip command may install the code is a system location like <code>/usr/lib/python3/dist-packages</code> or <code>~/.local/lib/python3.9/site-packages/</code> or something different.The <code>cli4 -e</code> command will try to decode the location and display the example files.</p><p dir="auto">If you are running release before Python 3.9 then you will be asked to install the following:</p><div class="highlight highlight-source-shell notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="$ pip install importlib_resources...$"><pre>$ pip install importlib_resources...$</pre></div><p dir="auto">It will show up if you are running on an older system. 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><p dir="auto">All API calls can be called from the command line via the <code>cli4</code> command.Additionally, the <code>cli4</code> command will convert domain name or account name prefixed with a colon (<code>:</code>) into the correct identifier.e.g. to view <code>example.com</code> you can use <code>cli4 /zones/:example.com</code>.You can pass the zone identifier (or account identifier or any identifier) with a colon followed by the identifier as a hex number 32 characters long.</p><div class="highlight highlight-source-shell notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="$ cli4 [-V|--version] [-h|--help] [-v|--verbose] \    [-e|--examples] \    [-q|--quiet] \    [-j|--json] [-y|--yaml] [-n|--ndjson] [-i|--image] \    [-r|--raw] \    [-d|--dump] \    [-A|--openapi url] \    [-b|--binary] \    [-p|--profile profile-name] \    [-h|--header additional-header] \    [--get|--patch|--post|--put|--delete] \    [item=value|item=@filename|@filename ...] /command ..."><pre>$ cli4 [-V<span class="pl-k">|</span>--version] [-h<span class="pl-k">|</span>--help] [-v<span class="pl-k">|</span>--verbose] \    [-e<span class="pl-k">|</span>--examples] \    [-q<span class="pl-k">|</span>--quiet] \    [-j<span class="pl-k">|</span>--json] [-y<span class="pl-k">|</span>--yaml] [-n<span class="pl-k">|</span>--ndjson] [-i<span class="pl-k">|</span>--image] \    [-r<span class="pl-k">|</span>--raw] \    [-d<span class="pl-k">|</span>--dump] \    [-A<span class="pl-k">|</span>--openapi url] \    [-b<span class="pl-k">|</span>--binary] \    [-p<span class="pl-k">|</span>--profile profile-name] \    [-h<span class="pl-k">|</span>--header additional-header] \    [--get<span class="pl-k">|</span>--patch<span class="pl-k">|</span>--post<span class="pl-k">|</span>--put<span class="pl-k">|</span>--delete] \    [item<span class="pl-k">=</span>value<span class="pl-k">|</span>item<span class="pl-k">=</span>@filename<span class="pl-k">|</span>@filename ...] /command ...</pre></div><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h3 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">CLI parameters for POST/PUT/PATCH</h3><a id="user-content-cli-parameters-for-postputpatch" class="anchor-element" aria-label="Permalink: CLI parameters for POST/PUT/PATCH" href="#cli-parameters-for-postputpatch"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><p dir="auto">For API calls that need to pass data or parameters there is various formats to use.</p><p dir="auto">The simplest form is <code>item=value</code>. This passes the value as a string within the APIs JSON data.</p><p dir="auto">If you need a numeric value passed then <code>==</code> can be used to force the value to be treated as a numeric value within the APIs JSON data.For example: <code>item==value</code>.</p><p dir="auto">if you need to pass a list of items; then <code>[]</code> can be used. For example:</p><div class="highlight highlight-source-shell notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="pool_id1="11111111111111111111111111111111"pool_id2="22222222222222222222222222222222"pool_id3="33333333333333333333333333333333"cli4 --post global_pools="[ ${pool_id1}, ${pool_id2}, ${pool_id3} ]" region_pools="[ ]" /user/load_balancers/maps"><pre>pool_id1=<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>11111111111111111111111111111111<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>pool_id2=<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>22222222222222222222222222222222<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>pool_id3=<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>33333333333333333333333333333333<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>cli4 --post global_pools=<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>[ <span class="pl-smi">${pool_id1}</span>, <span class="pl-smi">${pool_id2}</span>, <span class="pl-smi">${pool_id3}</span> ]<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span> region_pools=<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>[ ]<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span> /user/load_balancers/maps</pre></div><p dir="auto">Data or parameters can be either named or unnamed.It can not be both.Named is the majority format; as described above.Unnamed parameters simply don't have anything before the <code>=</code> sign, as in <code>=value</code>.This format is presently only used by the Cloudflare Load Balancer API calls.For example:</p><div class="highlight highlight-source-shell notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="cli4 --put ="00000000000000000000000000000000" /user/load_balancers/maps/:00000000000000000000000000000000/region/:WNAM"><pre>cli4 --put =<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>00000000000000000000000000000000<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span> /user/load_balancers/maps/:00000000000000000000000000000000/region/:WNAM</pre></div><p dir="auto">Data can also be uploaded from file contents. Using the <code>item=@filename</code> format will open the file and the contents uploaded in the POST.</p><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h3 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">CLI output</h3><a id="user-content-cli-output" class="anchor-element" aria-label="Permalink: CLI output" href="#cli-output"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><p dir="auto">The default output from the CLI command is in JSON.It can also output YAML format (i.e. human readable).This is controled by the <code>--yaml</code> or <code>--json</code> flags (JSON is the default).There is also a <code>--ndjson</code> flag for use with line based JSON data - this is mainly used for log data.</p><p dir="auto">Additonally the output can be plain text or binary image format depending on the results from the API call (some calls results in non JSON results).The <code>--image</code> flag will return the data in the same format as the API's results.</p><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h3 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">Simple CLI calls</h3><a id="user-content-simple-cli-calls" class="anchor-element" highlight-source-shell notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="$ $ cli4 --post name="test" type="A" content="10.0.0.1" /zones/:example.com/dns_records{    "id": "00000000000000000000000000000000",    "name": "test.example.com",    "type": "A",    "content": "10.0.0.1",    ...}$$ cli4 "content": "10.0.0.1"}$ cli4 --delete /zones/:example.com/dns_records/:test.example.com | jq -c .{"id":"00000000000000000000000000000000"}$"><pre>$ $ cli4 --post name=<span class="pl-s"><span values.See the API documentation for all the info.Here's an example of how to page thru a list of zones (it's included in the examples folder as <code>example_paging_thru_zones.sh</code>).Note the use of <code>==</code> to pass a number vs a string as paramater.</p><div class="highlight highlight-source-shell notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=":tmp=/tmp/$$_trap "rm ${tmp}; exit 0" 0 1 2 15PAGE=0while truedo        cli4 --raw per_page==5 page==${PAGE} /zones > ${tmp}        domains=`jq -c '.|.result|.[]|.name' < ${tmp} | tr -d '"'`        result_info=`jq -c '.|.result_info' < ${tmp}`        COUNT=`      echo "${result_info}" | jq .count`        PAGE=`       echo "${result_info}" | jq .page`        PER_PAGE=`   echo "${result_info}" | jq .per_page`        TOTAL_COUNT=`echo "${result_info}" | jq .total_count`        TOTAL_PAGES=`echo "${result_info}" | jq .total_pages`        echo COUNT=${COUNT} PAGE=${PAGE} PER_PAGE=${PER_PAGE} TOTAL_COUNT=${TOTAL_COUNT} TOTAL_PAGES=${TOTAL_PAGES} -- ${domains}        if [ "${PAGE}" == "${TOTAL_PAGES}" ]        then                ## last section                break        fi        # grab the next page        PAGE=`expr ${PAGE} + 1`done"><pre><span class="pl-c1">:</span>tmp=/tmp/<span class="pl-smi">$$</span>_<span See the API page in order to see which API calls do this.</p><div class="highlight highlight-source-shell notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="$ ACCOUNT_ID="00000000000000000000000000000000"$ LIST_ID="00000000000000000000000000000000"$$ cli4 --raw /accounts/::${ACCOUNT_ID}/rules/lists/::${LIST_ID}/items > /tmp/page1.json$ after=`jq -r '.result_info.cursors.after' < /tmp/page1.json`$ echo "after=$after"after=Mxm4GVmKjYbFjy2VxMPipnJigm1M_s6lCS9ABR9wx-RM2A$"><pre>$ ACCOUNT_ID=<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>00000000000000000000000000000000<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>$ LIST_ID=<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>00000000000000000000000000000000<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>$$ cli4 --raw /accounts/::<span class="pl-smi">${ACCOUNT_ID}</span>/rules/lists/::<span class="pl-smi">${LIST_ID}</span>/items <span class="pl-k">></span> /tmp/page1.json$ after=<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">`</span>jq -r <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>.result_info.cursors.after<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span> <span class="pl-k"><</span> /tmp/page1.json<span class="pl-pds">`</span></span>$ <span class="pl-c1">echo</span> <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>after=<span class="pl-smi">$after</span><span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>after=Mxm4GVmKjYbFjy2VxMPipnJigm1M_s6lCS9ABR9wx-RM2A$</pre></div><p dir="auto">Once we have the <code>after</code> value, we can pass it along in order to read the next hunk of values. We finish when <code>after</code> returns as null (or isn't present).</p><div class="highlight highlight-source-shell notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="$ cli4 --raw cursor="$after" /accounts/::${ACCOUNT_ID}/rules/lists/::${LIST_ID}/items > /tmp/page2.json$ after=`jq -r '.result_info.cursors.after' < /tmp/page2.json`$ echo "after=$after"after=null$"><pre>$ cli4 --raw cursor=<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span><span class="pl-smi">$after</span><span class="pl-pds">"</span></span> /accounts/::<span class="pl-smi">${ACCOUNT_ID}</span>/rules/lists/::<span class="pl-smi">${LIST_ID}</span>/items <span class="pl-k">></span> /tmp/page2.json$ after=<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">`</span>jq -r <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>.result_info.cursors.after<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span> <span class="pl-k"><</span> /tmp/page2.json<span class="pl-pds">`</span></span>$ <span class="pl-c1">echo</span> <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>after=<span class="pl-smi">$after</span><span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>after=null$</pre></div><p dir="auto">We can see the results now in two files.</p><div class="highlight highlight-source-shell notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" class="highlight highlight-source-python notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="    #    # "import" is a reserved word and hence we add '_' to the end of verb.    #    r = cf.zones.dns_records.import_.post(zone_id, files={'file':fd})"><pre>    <span class="pl-c">#</span>    <span class="pl-c"># "import" is a reserved word and hence we add '_' to the end of verb.</span>    <span class="pl-c">#</span>    <span class="pl-s1">r</span> <span class="pl-c1">=</span> <span class="pl-s1">cf</span>.<span class="pl-s1">zones</span>.<span class="pl-s1">dns_records</span>.<span class="pl-s1">import_</span>.<span class="pl-en">post</span>(<span class="pl-s1">zone_id</span>, <span class="pl-s1">files</span><span class="pl-c1">=</span>{<span class="pl-s">'file'</span>:<span class="pl-s1">fd</span>})</pre></div><p dir="auto">See <a href="https://github.com/cloudflare/python-cloudflare/tree/master/examples/example_dns_import.py">examples/example_dns_import.py</a> for working code.</p><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h3 data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="$ cli4 /zones/:example.com/dns_records/export | egrep -v '^;;|^$'$ORIGIN .@       3600    IN      SOA     example.com.    root.example.com. dns_records.splitlines():        if len(l) == 0 or l[0] == ';':            continue        print(l)    exit(0)if __name__ == '__main__':    main()"><pre><span class="pl-c">#!/usr/bin/env <span class="pl-s1">dns_records</span> <span class="pl-c1">=</span> <span class="pl-s1">cf</span>.<span class="pl-s1">zones</span>.<span class="pl-s1">dns_records</span>.<span class="pl-s1">export</span>.<span class="pl-en">get</span>(<span class="pl-s1">zone_id</span>)    <span class="pl-k">for</span> <span class="pl-s1">l</span> <span class="pl-c1">in</span> <span 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><p dir="auto">Cloudflare Workers are described on the Cloudflare blog at<a href="https://blog.cloudflare.com/introducing-cloudflare-workers/" rel="nofollow">here</a> and<a href="https://blog.cloudflare.com/code-everywhere-cloudflare-workers/" rel="nofollow">here</a>, with the beta release announced<a href="https://blog.cloudflare.com/cloudflare-workers-is-now-on-open-beta/" rel="nofollow">here</a>.</p><p dir="auto">The Python libraries now support the Cloudflare Workers API calls. The following javascript is lifted from <a href="https://cloudflareworkers.com/" rel="nofollow">https://cloudflareworkers.com/</a> and slightly modified.</p><div class="highlight highlight-source-shell notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="$ cat modify-body.jsaddEventListener("fetch", event => {  event.respondWith(fetchAndModify(event.request));});async function fetchAndModify(request) {  console.log("got a request:", request);  // Send the request on to the origin server.  const response = await fetch(request);  // Read response body.  const text = await response.text();  // Modify it.  const modified = text.replace(  "<body>",  "<body style=\"background: #ff0;\">");  // Return modified response.  return new Response(modified, {    status: response.status,    statusText: response.statusText,    headers: response.headers  });}$"><pre>$ cat modify-body.jsaddEventListener(<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>fetch<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, event =<span class="pl-k">></span> {  event.respondWith(fetchAndModify(event.request))<span class="pl-k">;</span>})<span class="pl-k">;</span>async <span class="pl-k">function</span> <span class="pl-en">fetchAndModify(request)</span> {  console.log(<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>got a request:<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, request)<span class="pl-k">;</span>  // Send the request on to the origin server.  const response = await fetch(request)<span class="pl-k">;</span>  // Read response body.  const text = await <span class="pl-en">response.text</span>();  // Modify it.  const modified = text.replace(  <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span><body><span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>,  <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span><body style=<span class="pl-cce">\"</span>background: #ff0;<span class="pl-cce">\"</span>><span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>)<span class="pl-k">;</span>  // Return modified response.  <span class="pl-k">return</span> new Response(modified, {    status: response.status,    statusText: response.statusText,    headers: response.headers  })<span class="pl-k">;</span>}$</pre></div><p dir="auto">Here's the website with it's simple <code><body></code> statement</p><div class="highlight highlight-source-shell notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="$ curl -sS https://example.com/ | fgrep '<body'  <body>$"><pre>$ curl -sS https://example.com/ <span class="pl-k">|</span> fgrep <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span><body<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>  <span class="pl-k"><</span>body<span class="pl-k">></span>$</pre></div><p dir="auto">Now lets add the script. Looking above, you will see that it's simple action is to modify the <code><body></code> statement and make the background yellow.</p><div class="highlight highlight-source-shell notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="$ cli4 --put @- /zones/:example.com/workers/script < modify-body.js{    "etag": "1234567890123456789012345678901234567890123456789012345678901234",    "id": "example-com",    "modified_on": "2018-02-15T00:00:00.000000Z",    "script": "addEventListener(\"fetch\", event => {\n  event.respondWith(fetchAndModify(event.request));\n});\n\nasync function fetchAndModify(request) {\n  console.log(\"got a request:\", request);\n\n  // Send the request on to the origin server.\n  const response = await fetch(request);\n\n  // Read response body.\n  const text = await response.text();\n\n  // Modify it.\n  const modified = text.replace(\n  \"<body>\",\n  \"<body style=\\\"background: #ff0;\\\">\");\n\n  // Return modified response.\n  return new Response(modified, {\n    status: response.status,\n    statusText: response.statusText,\n    headers: response.headers\n  });\n}\n",    "size": 603}$"><pre>$ cli4 --put @- /zones/:example.com/workers/script <span class="pl-k"><</span> modify-body.js{    <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>etag<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>: <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>1234567890123456789012345678901234567890123456789012345678901234<span class="pl-pds">"</span>2018-02-15T00:00:00.000000Z<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>,    <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>script<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>: <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>addEventListener(<span class="pl-cce">\"</span>fetch<span class="pl-cce">\"</span>, event => {\n  event.respondWith(fetchAndModify(event.request));\n});\n\nasync function fetchAndModify(request) {\n  console.log(<span class="pl-cce">\"</span>got a request:<span class="pl-cce">\"</span>, request);\n\n  // Send the request on to the origin server.\n  const response = await fetch(request);\n\n  // Read response body.\n  const text = await response.text();\n\n  // Modify it.\n  const modified = text.replace(\n  <span class="pl-cce">\"</span><body><span class="pl-cce">\"</span>,\n  <span class="pl-cce">\"</span><body style=<span class="pl-cce">\\\"</span>background: #ff0;<span class="pl-cce">\\\"</span>><span class="pl-cce">\"</span>);\n\n  // Return modified response.\n  return new Response(modified, {\n    status: response.status,\n    statusText: response.statusText,\n
